conclusion: Determine the length of the transparent part of the light entering perpendicular to the vertical diameter MN on the hemispherical lens.
The light source is at the focal point F of the paraboloid. The light is reflected by the paraboloid and enters the hemispherical lens perpendicular to the vertical diameter MN.

The radius R of the hemispherical lens is not given directly, but we can infer it from the geometry of the problem. The light enters the lens perpendicular to MN, which means it enters at the edge of the lens.
Snell's Law relates the angles of incidence and refraction: n1 sin θ1 = n2 sin θ2.
Here, n1 = 1 (air), n2 = 4/3 (lens), and θ1 = 90° (perpendicular entry).
Since θ1 = 90°, sin θ1 = 1. 1 * 1 = (4/3) sin θ2. sin θ2 = 3/4.
The light travels along a circular path inside the lens. The length of the transparent part is the arc length corresponding to the angle 2θ2 (since the light enters and exits symmetrically).
The circumference of the lens is 2πR.
The fraction of the circumference corresponding to 2θ2 is (2θ2/2π). The arc length is R * 2θ2.
θ2 = arcsin(3/4). The arc length is R * 2 * arcsin(3/4).
The length of the transparent part of all the light entering perpendicular to MN on the lens spherical surface is 2R * arcsin(3/4).
